question.title: the memory address of objects in Java even with using of a tool

node.contents: There are some unsafe() methods. But they are not safe and are not fast either. They are used with some fields and the address is relative. Not absolute. Then you gotta stick with some exception handling too! The only gain is the use of each byte no matter what the type of variable is. Its something like malloc() but without a [i] usage. You use setters and getters which has an overhead.

astNode.text: There are some unsafe() methods. But they are not safe and are not fast either. They are used with some fields and the address is relative. Not absolute. Then you gotta stick with some exception handling too! The only gain is the use of each byte no matter what the type of variable is. Its something like malloc() but without a [i] usage. You use setters and getters which has an overhead.

node.contents: I know it maybe is unsafe and not necessary but I just want know how the JVM is working. So I am not going to use it in a production.

node.contents: Is there a way in Java to see or write the heap address of an object. Say I have a Long Object

astNode.text: Is there a way in Java to see or write the heap address of an object. Say I have a Long Object

node.contents: I want to see the heap address of mylong instead of its value (1). I am just curious if it is possible! I know it is possible and may be it is not useful in the application. But I just looking for a way to know how the JVM is working in some cases.

astNode.text: I want to see the heap address of mylong instead of its value (1). I am just curious if it is possible! I know it is possible and may be it is not useful in the application. But I just looking for a way to know how the JVM is working in some cases.

node.contents: If you a tool which do this like an eclipse plugin I will appreciate if you let me know about it!

astNode.text: If you a tool which do this like an eclipse plugin I will appreciate if you let me know about it!

node.contents: do you know about a tool which can show me the current heap. I don't want to use it in a product! I just want to understand how the JVM is working. The unsafe method is not useful for me because I want to create the object exact as the jvm is doing

astNode.text: do you know about a tool which can show me the current heap. I don't want to use it in a product! I just want to understand how the JVM is working. The unsafe method is not useful for me because I want to create the object exact as the jvm is doing

node.contents: I would say the best tool is YourKit. You can get an eval license for free. It allows you to see the memory and cpu usage while the program is running, where objects are being created, and view a heap dump graphically.

astNode.text: I would say the best tool is YourKit. You can get an eval license for free. It allows you to see the memory and cpu usage while the program is running, where objects are being created, and view a heap dump graphically.

node.contents: Is there a way in Java to see or write the heap address of an object

astNode.text: Is there a way in Java to see or write the heap address of an object

node.contents: Long answer is; you don't want to as it's not useful. You can use Unsafe to get this information but the reference can change at any time.

astNode.text: Long answer is; you don't want to as it's not useful. You can use Unsafe to get this information but the reference can change at any time.

node.contents: Note: the reference is the address in 32-bit Java, but in 64-bit Java the reference is often multiplied by 8 and/or offset to allow the JVM to use 32-bit references for up to 32 GB of heap.

astNode.text: Note: the reference is the address in 32-bit Java, but in 64-bit Java the reference is often multiplied by 8 and/or offset to allow the JVM to use 32-bit references for up to 32 GB of heap.

node.contents: Not sure how this gives you the address of an Object.

astNode.text: Not sure how this gives you the address of an Object.

node.contents: allocateMemory is the address and it is long. You put any primitive or object value in there and use the address

astNode.text: allocateMemory is the address and it is long. You put any primitive or object value in there and use the address

node.contents: its the address of some allocated memory, but not the object.

astNode.text: its the address of some allocated memory, but not the object.

node.contents: Yes, i said it is **relative address** in my first comment to the question.

astNode.text: Yes, i said it is **relative address** in my first comment to the question.

elements.contents: import java.lang.reflect.Field; import sun.misc.Unsafe; public class Direct { public static void main(String... args) { Unsafe unsafe = null; try { Field field = sun.misc.Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); field.setAccessible(true); unsafe = (sun.misc.Unsafe) field.get(null); } catch (Exception e) { throw new AssertionError(e); } long value = 12345; byte size = 1; long allocateMemory = unsafe.allocateMemory(size); unsafe.putAddress(allocateMemory, value); long readValue = unsafe.getAddress(allocateMemory); System.out.println("read value : " + readValue); } }

units.rawText: import java.lang.reflect.Field; import sun.misc.Unsafe; public class Direct { public static void main(String... args) { Unsafe unsafe = null; try { Field field = sun.misc.Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); field.setAccessible(true); unsafe = (sun.misc.Unsafe) field.get(null); } catch (Exception e) { throw new AssertionError(e); } long value = 12345; byte size = 1; long allocateMemory = unsafe.allocateMemory(size); unsafe.putAddress(allocateMemory, value); long readValue = unsafe.getAddress(allocateMemory); System.out.println("read value : "+ readValue); } }
